awd_titl_txt: Impact of Aerosol and Boundary-Layer Interactions on the Development of Convective Clouds
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of our project are highlighted below:

1. A comprehensive review on aerosol and deep cloud interactions (Fan and Li, 2022)

Partially based on our own studies under this project, we have comprehensively and critically reviewed the advancement of aerosol-deep convective clouds (DCCs). The interactions depend on aerosol properties and meteorological conditions. For light-absorbing aerosol such as soot, they can change the meteorological conditions under which DCCs form through aerosol radiative effects. The radiative effects modify temperature profiles and planetary boundary layer heights, thus changing atmospheric stability and circulation, and impacting the onset and development of DCCs. The interaction is also dictated by aerosol hygroscopic properties that influence cloud droplet number. For a given water amount, higher cloud droplet concentrations lead to reduced droplet sizes, narrowing the droplet size spectrum, which may further result in freezing of more supercooled water, thereby (i) enhancing latent heating from ice-related microphysical processes and invigorating storms; (ii) modification of ice processes; (iii) expansion of the mixed-phase zone  (iv) slowing down of cloud dissipation, resulting in larger cloud cover.

2. A New Method of Determining the Planetary Boundary Layer (PBL) Height (Su et al., 2019)

Planetary boundary layer (PBL) processes play key roles in the initiation of convection and boundary-layer low clouds. Given the rapid change in the PBL over land, radiosondes cannot track the diurnal development of the PBL. We have developed a state-of-the-art automatic determination of PBL height using the combination of ground-based lidar (e.g., the MPL) and radiosonde data. While lidar-based backscatter profiles have been used to track the development of the PBL at high temporal and vertical resolutions, the previous approaches are only valid for well-mixed aerosol structures inside the PBL that change in harmony with the evolution of atmospheric thermodynamics. Its validity of application depends on atmospheric stability, and if there is any residual aerosol layer. If the latter is decoupled with the PBL, the approach is no longer applicable. To overcome these limitations, we have developed a novel method that can track diurnal variations of PBLH more accurately  (Su et al., 2019).

3. A novel method to determine the coupling between clouds and the surface over land (Su et al., 2022a)

As the first remote sensing method capable of obtaining a climatology of the coupling states, a deeper understanding of the development of continental boundary-layer clouds and their interactions with aerosols and the surface can be gained. Expanding on the idea for determining cloud coupling over oceans, an attempt was made to generalize the concept of coupling and decoupling of low clouds over land based on potential temperature profiles. Using ample measurements from the lidar and a suite of surface meteorological instruments installed at the ARM program's Southern Great Plains site, the planetary boundary layer height (PBLH) and coupled states under cloudy conditions during the daytime were simultaneously retrieved. The new lidar-based method relies on the PBLH, the lifted condensation level, and the cloud base height to diagnose the cloud coupling. The coupled states derived from this method are highly consistent with those derived from radiosondes. 

4. Discover the impact of aerosol vertical structure on lower atmosphere stability and its critical role in aerosol?planetary boundary layer (PBL) interactions (Su et al., 2022b) 

Our study is focused on the role of aerosol vertical distribution on thermodynamic stability and PBL development. Aerosol structures can be largely classified into three types: well-mixed, decreasing with height, and inverse structures. The aerosol-PBL relationship and diurnal cycles of the PBL height and PM2.5 associated with these different aerosol vertical structures show distinct characteristics. The vertical distribution of aerosol radiative forcing differs drastically among the three types with strong heating in the lower, middle, and upper PBL, respectively. Such a discrepancy in heating rate affects the atmospheric buoyancy and stability differently in the three distinct aerosol structures. Absorbing aerosols have a weak effect on stabilizing the lower atmosphere for the decreasing structure than for the inverse structure. 

5. Competing aerosol effects trigger convection over the Indo-Gangetic Plain (Manoj et al., 2021)

Deep convective clouds are an important component of the Asian monsoon. In recent years, aerosol effects on deep convection have garnered much attention. Our study led to a discovery that aerosols over the heavily polluted Indo-Gangetic Plain, located within the Asian monsoon domain, not only stabilize the lower atmosphere but in a seemingly contradictory way also favor deep convection due to a seminal role of aerosols in increasing the moist static energy through enhancement of internal energy. Although a heavy loading of absorbing aerosols might stabilize the planetary boundary layer and weaken the convection, observational analyses highlight the seminal role played by aerosols in increasing moist static energy, thus increasing the convective potential of the lower atmosphere. This leads to regional dynamical changes that trigger greater moisture feedback and regional precipitation.
